Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: My phone buzzes with a message from my younger brother: “Can you talk? It’s urgent.” I glance at the clock—just past 8 p.m.—and my laptop screen, where lines of code blink back at me. The new feature I’ve been building for weeks is almost done, but the last code review flagged performance issues. My team expects me to fix them before tomorrow’s demo. I know I should stay focused, refactor the code, and make sure it’s clean and efficient. But my brother never asks for help unless he really needs it. I imagine him sitting alone in his apartment, waiting for me to call, hoping I’ll be there for him like I always promised. My mind races, torn between the pressure to deliver flawless work and the responsibility to support my family. My hands hover over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I wrestle with the impossible choice between being the reliable sister he needs and the dependable developer my team counts on.
